greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest number that is n-persistent but not (n+1)-persistent, i.e., k, 2k, ..., nk, but not (n+1)k, are pandigital in the sense of A171102; 0 if such a number does not exist.
comment: a(9) is 0 because any 9-persistent number is also 10-persistent. Indeed, if n is pandigital, 10*n is pandigital as well.
In the same way, a(10m-1)=0 for all m>0 since if kn is pandigital for all k=1,...,10m-1, then mn is pandigital and so is 10mn.  - M. F. Hasler, Jan 10 2012
reference: Ross Honsberger, More Mathematical Morsels, Mathematical Association of America, 1991, pages 15-18.
example: k=36492195078 is the smallest number such that k, 2k, 3k, 4k, 5k, and 6k, each contain all ten digits, but 7k=255445365546 contains only five of the ten, so a(6)= 36492195078.
results.author: _Hans Havermann_, Jan 09 2012
